awd_titl_txt: OPP-PRF: Investigating 2.5k Years of Human History and Atmospheric Transport in Greenland Ice Using High-Resolution Lead Isotopic Records
awd_abstract_narration:
Polar ice sheets and glaciers  record changes in climate and the environment during recent decades, centuries, and millennia. Lead pollution found in cores extracted from polar ice sheets and glaciers reflects human activities, including mining and smelting related to early silver production, as well as coal, oil, and gasoline burning. Isotopic analyses of lead in glacier ice can be used to identify past changes in emission sources.  Lead isotopes will be measured in five Greenland ice cores to identify and quantify changes in Northern Hemisphere anthropogenic emission sources during the past 2500 years and to evaluate linkages between these changes and historical events extending from antiquity to the present. These records have the potential to transform understanding of how events such as plague, social upheaval, warfare, and technological advancements in mining and smelting influenced human history. The investigator will serve as an instructor for the Interdisciplinary Graduate and Early Career Researcher Consilience Workshop on Ice Core Science and Natural Archives in Fall 2022 sharing techniques and preliminary results and will participate in other outreach activities focused on improving accessibility and inclusivity in STEM fields. 
 
Lead (Pb) isotopes will be measured in existing discrete meltwater samples collected from four previously analyzed ice cores (NGRIP2, NASAU, RECAP, and NUUS_2015), as well as a fifth core (Tunu_2022) to be collected and analyzed in 2022 as part of an ongoing NSF project (1925417). Recently developed methods allow isotopic measurements of 206Pb, 207Pb, and 208Pb with low uncertainties at concentrations as low as 0.05 ng g-1, making high-resolution analyses in ice cores feasible. Refinement of these new methods as part of the proposed research may further increase resolution and improve interpretive power by reducing required concentrations (down to 0.02 ng g-1) and measurement uncertainties of low abundance 204Pb. If successful, such 204Pb measurements would be among the first used to interpret polar ice records. The proposed measurements will improve resolution of pre-20th-century Pb isotopic records from ice, particularly those from antiquity and the medieval period, for which only a handful of values have been published. Evaluation will leverage collaborations between Desert Research Institute and ancient historians, archaeologists, and atmospheric scientists. The detailed Pb source apportionment resulting from this research will be used to evaluate the accuracy of atmospheric transport and deposition models widely used for ice core interpretation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report:

The impacts of societal changes throughout human history have had a well-documented influence on hemispheric-scale lead pollution records for at least the past 2500 years. However, source tracing of this lead is largely limited to the mid-20th century owing to the low concentrations of lead in ice. High-resolution lead isotopic measurements in polar ice cores potentially provide means of identifying and tracing sources of lead pollution to their origin. Here we developed high resolution records of lead isotopic ratios from four ice cores (RECAP, NGRIP2, and Tunu2022a and Tunu2022b) dated from 500 BCE to 2022 CE.

Intellectual Merit.

Natural and Anthropogenic Lead: High-resolution continuous flow analysis records of lead and dust linked to discrete samples used during this study allow for the removal of the crustal lead component from the total lead isotopic ratios. Removal of the crustal fraction allowed for better constraints on anthropogenic lead sources within each core.

Antiquity: Lead isotopic records suggest strong influence from Iberian lead sources, likely dominated by mining in southeastern Spain. Increases in the isotopic ratios of 206Pb/207Pb in the first century CE may reflect enhanced emissions from the Roman conquest of Britain, which led to expanded mining and smelting operations. Isotopic ratios from NGRIP2 from Antiquity (500 BCE – 500 CE) agree well with previous records from the GRIP ice core but provide approximately three times the number of measurements.

Middle Ages: This study provides the first high resolution ice core records spanning the Middle Ages and Early Modern periods. The Early Modern is characterized by oscillations in predominantly silver and gold monetary systems, with substantial lead stemming from natural lead sources. Just before the Black Death (1300–1347 CE), lead isotopic ratios reflect predominantly western European sources. Interestingly, the onset of the Black Death in 1348 CE does not coincide with the drop in lead pollution or changes in lead isotopic ratios, suggesting a continuation of smelting activities through the first phase of the plague. This suggests that the high mortality rate did not immediately reduce mining and smelting operations, but that a decrease in demand caused reductions and closures of smelters sites. Following a century-long period of sustained low lead concentrations ending around 1450 CE, lead concentrations and lead isotopic ratios reflect a mixture of European and likely Iberian lead smelting. Beginning in the 16th century isotopic ratios shift as a result of German mining and smelting.

Modern: Records from the Tunu2022b core mirror records from the Summit2010 ice core (Wensman et al., 2022, Anthropocene). As with the Summit2010 record lead isotopic ratios show a shift from predominantly U.S. sources in the 1970s, to predominantly Chinese sources during beginning in the 2000s.

Broader Impacts:

The project contributed to the training of a post-doctoral associate and one master’s student. The master’s student is now a scientist at the EPA, and the post-doc is still at DRI. The PI conveyed findings to the public by contributing to public lecture series.

Products:

The detailed measurements from the Tunu2022a, Tunu2022b, RECAP, and NGRIP2 ice cores have been posted to the Arctic Data Center (doi: 10.18739/A28S4JR2J). Datasets also have been posted with specific publications in readily available journal websites.
